block.p: Seana Lee Wyman, the daughter of Rosemarie A. Wyman of Brooklyn and Henry E. Wyman of Buffalo, was married in New York yesterday to Frank Nelson Bradley, a son of Noel and William J. Bradley, also of Buffalo. Michael Gage, a former administrative judge of the New York City Family Court, officiated.

The bride and bridegroom, both 30, work at Ernst & Young, the accounting firm in New York. She is an office manager, and he is a database manager. The bride, who is also an actress, and the bridegroom, also a playwright, worked together in ''Black Mask,'' a homage to 1930's and 40's detective fiction, written by Mr. Bradley and staged in 1998 by the Ontological-Hysteric Theater, Off Off Broadway.

The bride and bridegroom, both 30, work at Ernst & Young, the accounting firm in New York. She is an office manager, and he is a database manager. The bride, who is also an actress, and the bridegroom, also a playwright, worked together in ''Black Mask,'' a homage to 1930's and 40's detective fiction, written by Mr. Bradley and staged in 1998 by the Ontological-Hysteric Theater, Off Off Broadway.

Ms. Wyman, who is keeping her name, graduated from St. Bonaventure University in Olean, N.Y. Her mother is a supervising court attorney in Manhattan Criminal Court. Her father manages three restaurants in Buffalo.

Mr. Bradley graduated from the State University at Buffalo. His mother is the office manager of Nelson, Heinz & Shookus, manufacturers' representatives in Buffalo. His father retired as a painter for Buffalo General Hospital. The bridegroom is a grandson of Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the Army commander in Vietnam from 1968 to 1972 and then the Army's chief of staff.

The couple met in September 1992, attending classes at SUNY's Buffalo campus. They performed together in Lanford Wilson's ''Hot l Baltimore.'' They were dating others at the time and would occasionally double date.
''After knowing Frank for eight or nine months, I found that I had more fun talking to him than my date,'' Ms. Wyman said, explaining what changed the status quo.
They moved to New York City in November 1993, finding day jobs and continuing to perform together.

When Mr. Bradley was ready to propose marriage, he chose when and where he wanted to play the scene, but it did not go as planned. A few days before then, they were having lunch in Midtown Manhattan. He had just picked up the engagement ring. As they sat at the table, he told her a joke. She laughed and smacked his leg playfully. It was then that she felt the box in his pocket.
''I had no choice but to tell her in the Le Croissant shop,'' Mr. Bradley said. ''I'm a terrible liar, so I had to tell the truth.''
